page.title: 01Catacol,Glen of Wild Cat
page.content: The majestic and sometimes preciptous mountainous landward view is impressive to mind and eye providing very limited feeding for a few cattle, or sheep, with wild Red Deer roaming the mountain tops. The Glen has an abundant variety of wild life, from Shrews to Mountain Hares, from Eagles,Buzzards, Finches, Waxwings in winter, wild swans, various ducks. Herons and dippers. Seaward you can see basking sharks in summer, seals in winter with an odd shoal of Mackeral, Herring and Whitebait. There is a very short tree and older line above shore level, and the only change in 2000 years are few small houses called '12 apostles' and a small shore line road, where a bus runs twice a day, 6 days a week. The Wild Cats which gave Catacol its name have now been exterminated, although stories
